Authors: Kaleido L.
Title: 3D prototypes help track design trends
Abstract: PI3 is turning traditional structural packaging into three-dimensional prototypes to track packaging design trends. The company's in-house innovation lab is equipped with CNC lathe and milling machines, and allows three-dimensional data to be taken directly from a designer's computer, preventing distortion or misinterpretation in the design stream. PI3's lab also developed its own technique for producing blown PET bottles using three-dimensional methods as final manufacture. PI3 plans to help companies anticipate long-term packaging design issues according to new and emerging technology developments market and consumer trends.
Index Keywords: Computer aided design; Computer aided manufacturing; Cost effectiveness; Costs; Customer satisfaction; Dispensers; Marketing; Reusability; Sales; Software prototyping; Consumer brands; Packaging design; PI3 (CO); Structural packaging; Packaging; Cad Cam; Computer Programs; Costs; Packaging; Prototypes; Technical Services

Authors: Braga F., Laterza M.
Title: Field testing of low-rise base isolated building
Abstract: A series of dynamic snap-back tests were carried out on a residence building in southern Italy at Rapolla (Potenza-Basilicata). The aim of the research was to investigate the seismic behaviour of low-rise base isolated structures mounted on rubber bearings only, or with a hybrid isolation system (sliding bearings for isolation and steel rubber bearings to have a re-centring force). High initial displacements (up to 170 mm) were reached using a reusable mechanical device, and a 200 t reaction wall. The paper presents the experimental study performed and its main results. As far as the protection level is concerned, the experimental response of the structure on the hybrid isolation system and on the steel rubber isolation system has been compared with the code seismic actions confirming the effectiveness of both tested isolation systems. © 2004 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Base isolation; Elastomeric bearings; Free vibration; Full-scale experimental tests; Reaction wall; Seismic isolation; Sliding bearings
Index Keywords: Bearings (structural); Research; Seismology; Steel; Field testing; Isolation system; Rubber bearings; Buildings; earthquake engineering; seismic response; structural response; vibration

Authors: Wilk P.
Title: Adapt & re-use
Abstract: The use of structural steel for the renovation and expansion of Mary mount Middle school in Manhattan to meet the challenges of time, space and budget is discussed. A masonary bearing wall and a steel frame is used to provide a column-free space and skylights for the ground floor commons room. The renovation project required fabrication of approximately 70W12×45s to support the existing five-story brick bearing wall. The steel is coated with spray applied fire-protective coating to give it a two-hour fire rating.
Index Keywords: Fire-protective coatings; Renovation process; Structural elements; Wooden structures; Brick; Budget control; Concrete construction; Crack initiation; Elevators; Facades; Fire protection; Lighting fixtures; Reusability; Scheduling; Steel structures; Stiffness; Strategic planning; Structural design; Structural frames; Welding machines; Steel construction

Authors: Angelo W.J.
Title: Grabbing the lucrative adaptive reuse market
Abstract: The need of grabbing the adaptive reuse market is discussed. The adaptive reuse at older buildings can provide a creative and rewarding market. Instead of demolishing older buildings in urban areas, developers are reusing them for new purposes. There are many advantages to reuse, it is less costly then demolition, new zoning density hassles and new construction requirements.
Index Keywords: Adaptive reuse; Design-build; Project utilization; Residential structures; Urban buildings; Buildings; Costs; Investments; Marketing; Project management; Reusability; Structural design; Warehouses; Construction industry

Authors: Stansfield K.
Title: How can geotechnics address sustainability?
Abstract: The relationship between geotechnical and structural engineers that could be developed to ensure sustainable construction methods was discussed at IStructE's conference on turning sustainability into reality. Geotechnics has a long term impact on the economy in the provision of infrastructure, transport services, and buildings. There is more pressure to re-use existing infrastructure and buildings, but dealing with risk and liability are likely to take preference over sustainability. Improved sustainability means that a balance has to be struck between all the aspects of energy and materials in use, in production, transport, construction operation and reuse or demolition of a structure.
Index Keywords: Economic growth; Landfill tax; Reuse; Sustainable construction; Economics; Environmental impact; Excavation; Foundations; Geothermal energy; Land fill; Landforms; Risk assessment; Social aspects; Structural design; Sustainable development; Geotechnical engineering

Authors: Pulaski M., Hewitt C., Horman M., Guy B.
Title: Design for deconstruction
Abstract: The need for designing the deconstruction is discussed to increases efficiency in a building's adaptability and disassembly. It also reduces the impact of pollution and recovers building materials for reuse and recycling. The design elements that simplifies the disassembly effort and reduces the labor laws for processing are incorporated to improve the efficiency and economic benefits of deconstruction. The designers and contractors provide practical guidance for effectively incorporating building-wide deconstruction principles into the design principles. The principles are design for prefabrication, preassembly and modular constrution, simplify and standardize connection details and design to accomodate deconstruction logistics, reusable materials.
Index Keywords: Building disassembly; Construction-safety hazards; Deconstruction; Prefabrication; Adhesives; Costs; Environmental impact; Fasteners; Life cycle; Metal casting; Prefabricated construction; Recycling; Reusability; Scheduling; Sealants; Standards; Structural design; Toxicity; Waste utilization; Building materials

Authors: Laefer D.F., O'Brien W.J., Steiner R.L.
Title: Integrated modeling agenda for sustainable communities via reconfigurability
Abstract: Sustainability in the construction industry can only be achieved through a radical rethinking of building construction and reuse. This paper outlines the problems and offers innovative solutions that embrace technological innovations, advances in manufacturing and distribution, and integration of building and land use concepts through: 1) application of a dismountable and reconfigurable structural system, 2) promotion of the concept of kitting, and 3) reconceptualization of the relationships between construction management, engineering, supply chain configurations, environmental modeling, design, and urban planning. Basic components are described with the modeling and research agenda needed to make these solutions both viable and adoptable.
Index Keywords: Contamination; Costs; Environmental impact; Mathematical models; Reengineering; Reusability; Solid wastes; Urban planning; Construction management; Environmental modeling; Integrated modeling; Reconfigurability; Construction industry

Authors: Finger G.W.
Title: Cost effective evolution of NASA's launch infrastructure
Source title: A Collection of Technical Papers - AIAA Space 2004 Conference and Exposition
Abstract: NASA's ground based launch infrastructure represents an important National asset which is being underutilized by the scaled back Space Shuttle program. The Integrate -Transfer - Launch (ITL) process developed in the 1960's for Saturn V and utilized for Shuttle presents a flexible solution for accommodating new and evolved vehicles and even multiple programs. This infrastructure is currently undergoing major multimillion dollar restoration which will maintain its structural functionality for years to come. As the Nation plans its transition from Shuttle to follow on vehicles (such as Crew Exploration Vehicle and cargo vehicles), it is important we also plan a rational and cost effective evolution of these ground based assets. This paper discusses the basic capabilities, evolution options and cost impacts of these options.
Index Keywords: Boosters (rocket); Cost effectiveness; Industrial economics; Launching; Maintenance; Personnel; Process control; Reusability; Space applications; Integrate transfer launch (ITL) process; Solid rocket boosters; Space launches; Vehicle assembly building; Space shuttles

Authors: Hang W.Y.W., Howe A.S.
Title: Deployable secondary support structures for planetary construction
Abstract: This research explores shape grammars and design principles for the development of component-based (kit-of-parts) foundation systems, secondary structure, and environmentally responsive building elements for planetary habitat construction. The study includes a survey of different foundation systems that can be used when the construction site is on a slope, rocks, variable terrain, liquid surface, or immersed within a liquid (Howe, 2000). Since most of the high priority sites with scientific interests present some difficulties for landing and setting up research stations (Cohen, 1998), this study investigates how the substructure can deploy and help to settle or establish a reliable platform for primary structures, based on the idea of a kit-of-parts system. Since the interface with the primary structures is important to have unified structural system, the model of the primary structures would be based on the characteristics of Class II Space habitats (Kennedy, 2002). Although in the discussion, Class I and Class III habitats would be involved, this is to ensure some structural components used in Class I can be reused in Class II development and help to construct or deploy Class III habitats. The focus is on self-deployable secondary support structures that minimize the space occupied in launching and provide large, lightweight structures that are low-cost (Tsunoda & Senbokuya, 2002a). The foldability during stowage, and unfoldablitiy during set up are crucial criteria in the selection of structure (Cohen, 1986), therefore the procedure for packing, stowage, launching, deployment and maintenance is discussed in the paper (Kronenburg, 1996). © 2003 by A. Scott Howe. Published by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc.
Index Keywords: Construction sites; Foundation systems; Planetary habitats; Primary structures; Secondary structures; Secondary supports; Structural component; Structural systems; Cargo handling; Ground supports; Liquids; Navigation; Roadway supports; Stowage (mines); Ecosystems

Authors: Brinkerhoff G.Z.
Title: RSRM case acceptance and refurbishment requirements designed to satisfy structural, fracture and safety criteria
Source title: 39th AIAA/ASME/SAE/ASEE Joint Propulsion Conference and Exhibit
Abstract: The RSRM (Reuseable Solid Rocket Motor) Program has been developed and implemented to support manned flight space travel. The Space Shuttle Vehicle utilizes two SRBs (Solid Rocket Boosters) to assist during the launch sequence and achieve the predefined orbit and mission objectives. A critical feature of this program involves postflight SRB retrieval, disassembly and reuse of case structural components to manufacture future RSRM motors. To ensure these components can be safely reused, inspection criteria based on dimensional, structural and fracture requirements, has been established in the form of Engineering specifications and drawings. These criteria originated from actual hardware testing (both subscale and full scale) coupled with conventional Engineering hand calculations and computerized Finite Element Analyses (FEA). The intent of this paper is to provide an overview of the RSRM Case component refurbishment requirements and the associated case hardware inspection and evaluation processes that has been established to satisfy these requirements. Many of these processes have been recently upgraded to comply with environmental regulations, obsolescence concerns and technological advancements. Qualification of these process changes has been closely monitored and documented through test plans and reports. © 2003 by ATK, Thiokol Propulsion, a Division of ATK Aerospace Company.
Index Keywords: Critical features; Engineering specification; Inspection and evaluations; Mission objectives; Solid rocket boosters; Solid rocket motors; Structural component; Technological advancement; Automobile manufacture; Computer software reusability; Environmental regulations; Finite element method; Hardware; Obsolescence; Propulsion; Rocket engines; Rockets; Space shuttles; Fracture

Authors: Hald H., Ullmann T.
Title: Reentry flight and ground testing experience with hot structures of C/C-SiC material
Source title: 44th AIAA/ASME/ASCE/AHS/ASC Structures, Structural Dynamics, and Materials Conference
Abstract: Hot structures of ceramic matrix composites (CMC) which are based on carbon fiber reinforced materials like C/C-SiC are a well known key technology of light weight thermal protection systems (TPS) of advanced and reusable space reentry vehicles. Due to technical limitations with ground based test facilities, real flight testing of hot structures on operational vehicles in terms of validation of materials and design concepts is certainly the most important issue. In the past ten years, multiple reentry flight tests with samples and structural components of DLR's C/CSiC material have been performed. In this paper some TPS flight experiments are described in detail, beginning with first material specimens, which were integrated into the ablative heat shield of Russian FOTON capsules in 1992 and 1994. With more complex C/C-SiC structures like the CETEX (CEramic Tile EXperiment) experiment which was flown during the EXPRESS mission in early 1995 and further developments as the nose cap structure of NASA's X-38 vehicle, it was intended to evaluate latest design concepts and improved coating systems as integral part of a TPS structure. Consequently a new reentry experiment was set up in 2001 which was also integrated into the ablative heat shield of the new FOTON-M1 capsule series. Unfortunately the launch of the Soyuz carrier system in October 2002 failed and the FOTON capsule was destroyed approximately 20 seconds after lift-off. Material relevant experience gained by reentry flight experiments is correlated with the results achieved by extended ground testing and some considerations based on theoretical models. During reentry, physical limits for C/C-SiC material are defined by oxidation resistance, passive-active transition conditions and erosion effects. Special emphasis is given to the passive-active transition behavior of SiC and the related 'temperature jump effect'. Finally the behavior of different anti oxidation coating systems and their suitability for this purpose are considered. © 2003 by DLR, German Aerospace Center. Published by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc.
Index Keywords: Anti-oxidation coatings; Further development; Ground based tests; Structural component; Technical limitations; Thermal Protection System; Transition behavior; Transition conditions; Ceramic matrix composites; Coatings; Experiments; Fiber reinforced materials; Heat shielding; NASA; Silicon carbide; Structural dynamics; Reentry

Authors: Su X., Abdi F.
Title: Progressive failure analysis of RLV laminates of IM7/PETI-5 - at high, room, and cryogenic temperatures
Source title: 44th AIAA/ASME/ASCE/AHS/ASC Structures, Structural Dynamics, and Materials Conference
Abstract: In order to increase the reliability of the next generation of space transportation systems, the mechanical behavior of polymeric matrix composite (PMC) materials at critical design temperatures was investigated. This paper presents a comparison of analytical life prediction methodology (Figure 1) and experimentally observed test data on the residual mechanical properties of a carbon fiber polymeric composite, IM7/PETI-5, both before and after aging. The intent of this effort was to provide a validated analytical design tool for cryogenic tank applications. The simulation effort consisted of: 1) Progressive Failure Analysis (PFA) prediction of the mechanical behavior, damage and failure mechanisms of the Reusable Launch Vehicle (RLV) laminates, 2) Material Uncertainty Analyzer (MUA), that established a relationship between the constituent properties, laminate strength, and failure mechanisms, and 3) permeability prediction of the RLV by PFA, which generated exhausted strain energy curves (damage energy curves). The simulation results are consistent with tests conducted at NASA-Langley. Simulation results revealed that: 1) damage initiation strength of the laminate depends on the matrix properties because damage initiates as the matrix fails, 2) final failure strength of the laminate is determined mainly by fiber properties, and 3) the variation of the constituent properties has more influence on the laminate final strength than on the laminate damage initiation strength.
Index Keywords: Cryogenic temperatures; Life-prediction methodology; Material uncertainty; Permeability prediction; Polymeric matrix composites; Progressive failure analysis; Re-usable launch vehicles (RLV); Space Transportation System; Carbon fibers; Mechanical engineering; Mechanical properties; NASA; Reusability; Structural dynamics; Laminates

Authors: Messinger R., Pulley J.
Title: Thermal-mechanical cyclic test of a composite cryogenic tank for reusable launch vehicles
Source title: 44th AIAA/ASME/ASCE/AHS/ASC Structures, Structural Dynamics, and Materials Conference
Abstract: Cyclic testing was performed on an 8- foot diameter reusable composite hydrogen tank at NASA MSFC from November 1998 through February 2000. The tank was built as part of a risk reduction program for an anticipated Single-Stage to Orbit (SSTO) Reusable Launch Vehicle (RLV) program sponsored by NASA (Cooperative Agreement NCC8-39 for Technology Development of Reusable Composite Liquid Hydrogen Tank System). The tank was designed and assembled by the Tulsa Division of Rockwell (now Boeing), with the tooling and fiber-placed structure fabricated by Alliant Techsystems in Utah. A pretest series of checkout tests was completed that included ten liquid nitrogen cycles. A cycle consists filling tank with cryogen, pressurizing to operating pressure, applying ascent load, relieving load and pressure, draining tank, applying heat, applying descent load, cooling TPS, and warming of the tank wall. Twenty-six cycles with liquid hydrogen were then successfully completed. A burst test with LN2 was conducted February 29, 2000 - burst occurred at 106% of ultimate. Strain, acoustic emission, temperature, and micro-photographic results are presented. © 2003 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Alliant techsystems; Composite cryogenic tanks; Composite hydrogen tanks; Cooperative agreements; Liquid hydrogen tanks; Re-usable launch vehicles (RLV); Reusable launch vehicles; Technology development; Computer software reusability; Cryogenic liquids; Launching; Liquefied gases; NASA; Reusability; Reusable rockets; Structural dynamics; Tanks (containers)

Authors: Butler Jr. D.T., Aboudi J., Arnold S.M., Pindera M.-J.
Title: RLV thrust cell liner coating analysis and design considerations
Source title: 44th AIAA/ASME/ASCE/AHS/ASC Structures, Structural Dynamics, and Materials Conference
Abstract: This study addresses the relative impact of cooling channel wall and protective thermal coating thickness on the deformation fields of reusable launch vehicle (RLV) thrust cell liners under in-service loading conditions. The ultimate objective is to identify an optimum liner and coating design that produces stress and deformation fields leading to improved life/durability. A reference case based on the work of previous studies is introduced and subsequent changes in geometry and materials are investigated. Analyses are accomplished through the application of the cylindrical version of the higher-order theory for functionally graded materials/structural components. This theory provides a unique analytical tool for the design of advanced aircraft engine structural components with active cooling channels based on the concept of functionally graded material architectures through which improved deformation and life can be attained. The sensitivity of the cooling channel wall deformation to changes in the wall thickness is demonstrated which is commensurate with the observed failure mode. Most importantly, the presence of a NiCrAlY thermal barrier coating is shown to substantially reduce the cooling channel wall distortion. © 2003 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Deformation field; Design considerations; Functionally graded; Higher-order theory; Loading condition; Re-usable launch vehicles (RLV); Stress and deformation; Structural component; Aircraft engines; Coatings; Cooling; Design; Functionally graded materials; Reusability; Structural dynamics; Thermal barrier coatings; Thickness measurement; Deformation

Authors: Iwata T., Sawada K., Kamijo K., Niiyama Y.
Title: Preliminary analysis of liquid air cycle engine for two stage RLV
Source title: 12th AIAA International Space Planes and Hypersonic Systems and Technologies
Abstract: A conceptual study of two stage reusable launch vehicle powered by the liquid air cycle engine (LACE) is performed in this paper. The vehicle launches vertically and landing horizontally, and the booster flies back to launch site. The propulsion system of the booster is LACE/LRE combined cycle engine. To determine the performance of LACE mode, experimental and analytical studies of a compact heat exchanger for LACE is performed. A comparison between LACE powered booster with LRE powered booster, which using a common orbiter, is performed. It is found that the total weight of LACE booster becomes almost comparable with that of LRE system because of the increased structural mass for LH2 tank and also for liquefaction system. In this paper, we could not find clear advantages of using LACE boosters. © 2003 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Analytical studies; Compact heat exchanger; Conceptual study; Liquefaction systems; Preliminary analysis; Propulsion system; Reusable launch vehicles; Structural mass; Air; Liquefied gases; Reusability; Engines

Authors: Van Der Heide E.J., Kruijff M., Avanzini A., Liedtke V., Karlovsky A.
Title: Thermal protection testing of the inflatable capsule for YES2
Source title: 54th International Astronautical Congress of the International Astronautical Federation (IAF), the International Academy of Astronautics and the International Institute of Space Law
Abstract: The YES2 (2nd Young Engineers' Satellite) project employs An Inherently safe Re-entry (AIR) vehicle that will be de-orbited by the means of a 30 km polyethylene (Dyneema) tether. Low mass, large drag area concept design options are pursued for the reentry vehicle. In these concepts, the mass of the capsule is kept to several kilograms only through strongly reduced payload requirements, as well as through jettison of most instrumentation and structure shortly before entry. Due to the low ballistic coefficient the capsule will decelerate in the upper layers of the atmosphere, thus reducing aerodynamic and thermal loads. This approach allows for new lightweight materials (Nextel, aerogel, foams) and inflatable structural design concepts. A matrix of lightweight flexible Thermal Protection System material assemblies have been tested at the AMTT test house in August 2003. Two testing facilities have been used: the newly developed Re-entry Simulation chamber and the Universal Testing Machine. This paper lists the first results of the first YES2 TPS material testing campaign, of which the objectives are twofold. Firstly to characterize the gradient/conductivity of the assembled TPS for the YES2 re-entry vehicle concepts in a high radiation, low pressure, hot gas environment (impact different materials, multi-layer, surface porosity etc.). Secondly to determine non-documented break strength ft strain of material fabrics.
Index Keywords: Ball burst tests; Fabric break force testing; Material fabrication; Re-entry simulation chambers; Actuators; Ceramic materials; Computer aided design; Damping; Oxidation; Reusability; Robustness (control systems); Silicon carbide; Space research; Spacecraft

Authors: Swanson D.B., Varney G., Siu J.
Title: The structural engineers role in disaster preparedness, response, and recovery
Source title: Proceedings of the Structures Congress and Exposition
Abstract: An overview of the newly created NCSEA Structural Engineers Emergency Response Program (SEERProgram) was presented. The SEERPlan is a comprehensive document that enables member SEAs and other engineering organizations to 'put into place' emergency preparedness, response and recovery programs to aid public agencies and private entities following disasters. An overview of the Structural Engineers role in disaster response as it relates to the FEMA Urban Search and Reuse Program was also provided. It provides insight and guidance on how to implement training and preparedness plans, and how to organize local area engineers on a state-by-state basis to be ready to respond after a disaster.
Index Keywords: Disaster response; Natural disasters; Structural Engineering Associations (SEA); Structural Engineers Emergency Response Committee (SEERCommittee); Bridges; Buildings; Dams; Decision making; Disaster prevention; Disasters; Environmental impact; Ports and harbors; Societies and institutions; Tanks (containers); Structural design

Authors: Müller J., Zauner C.
Title: Low shock release unit - Easy resettable and 100% reusable
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Abstract: The paper presents a non explosive, easy resettable low shock release unit which can be actuated multiple times without any refurbishment (100 % reusable). The current design is able to release a tensile load of 16 kN at a weight of approx. 475 grams. The qualification testing is finished. An unit with an enhanced load capability is under investigation. The current unit is designed for a holddown & release mechanism of solar arrays; however various applications are possible. The release unit principle is the conversion of tensile preload into rotational energy, providing a smooth preload relief within a short time. After actuation, the unit can be easily reset instantly. Neither replacement nor refurbishment of any component parts is necessary. This 100 % reusability and the related savings of costs for refurbishment or replacements are unique features. The unit functional principle and the results of the performed qualification programme are presented hereafter.
Index Keywords: Actuators; Reusability; Shock testing; Structural loads; Refurbishment; Light weight structures

Authors: Hendriks Ch.F., Janssen G.M.T.
Title: Use of recycled materials in constructions
Abstract: There are several options for the use of recycled materials in constructions. For every option a number of technical and environmental aspects are relevant. This paper describes several models which can be used to take the optimal decision. In general the world-wide used Life Cycle Assessment can be used as a multi-parameter model for the environmental effects. A new single indicator model, the Eco-costs/Value ratio simplifies the decision process. For waste management the model called Delft Ladder is developed. The approach called Design for Recycling can be used to optimize design of constructions for later reuse. In the same way, the Design for Disassembly can be used for demolition. For the technical aspects two models were developed concerning degradation processes and high-graded applications.
Index Keywords: Demolition; Life cycle; Recycling; Structural design; Sustainable development; Design for disassembly; Multi parameter model; Recycled materials; Building materials

Authors: Kott M., Künzel E.
Title: Construction and planning considerations in the development of structural systems for sustainable buildings made of precast reinforced concrete [Konstruktive und entwurfsplanerische aspekte bei der entwicklung von bausystemen für kreislaufgerechte gebäude aus stahlbetonfertigteilen]
Source title: Betonwerk und Fertigteil-Technik/Concrete Precasting Plant and Technology
Abstract: An overview is given of the results of a sub-project dealing with issues of development, planning and implementation of structural systems for sustainable buildings made of precast reinforced concrete. It is shown that the current regulations and norms regarding the choice and use of building materials provide sufficient information on planning and implementation for the use of long-lasting, demountable reinforced concrete parts. On the basis of criteria such as ease of assembly and disassembly, reusability and design requirements the criteria for selecting structural systems, ties and elements are provided.
Index Keywords: Precast industry; Precast reinforced concrete; Structural systems; Buildings; Environmental protection; Planning; Precast concrete; Production; Reinforced concrete; Structural analysis; Sustainable development; Concrete industry

Authors: Cusidó J.A., Cremades L.V., González M.
Title: Gaseous emissions from ceramics manufactured with urban sewage sludge during firing processes
Abstract: The re-use of sewage sludge without any treatment as primary material - mixed with clays - in order to obtain structural ceramics for buildings has been successfully improved. In the Ecobrick® project, the firing of a mixture of specific percentages of three components (clays, sludges and forest debris) resulted in a lighter and more thermal and acoustic insulating brick, compared with conventional clay-bricks. Volatile organic compounds (VOC) emission from the manufacturing of ceramics is the most important aspect to control. In the Ecobrick® project VOC emissions were monitored by using a bench-scale furnace. The study was conducted using an EPA recommended sampling train and portable sampling tubes that were thermally desorbed and analyzed by gas chromatography/mass spectrometry. Drying of raw sewage-sludge and firing processes were considered separately. In this paper, we present VOC emissions coming from the firing step of the Ecobrick® production. © 2002 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Clay; Desorption; Firing (of materials); Gas chromatography; Gas emissions; Mass spectrometry; Reusability; Sound insulating materials; Structural ceramics; Thermal insulation; Volatile organic compounds; Forest debris; Sewage sludge; ceramics; emission; recycling; sewage treatment; sludge; article; building material; ceramics; clay; furnace; gas chromatography; mass spectrometry; priority journal; recycling; sludge; Air Pollution, Indoor; Ceramics; Hazardous Waste; Humans; Organic Chemicals; Refuse Disposal; Sewage; Volatilization

Authors: Büyükdigan I.
Title: A critical look at the new functions of Ottoman baths
Abstract: A large number of baths, which have been one of the focus of communal life throughout the history of Anatolia and the Balkans, were built especially in the second half of the 14th and in the 15th centuries. But only a very few of the many buildings have retained their original function and have kept their authentic vitality. The majority of these baths have lost their functions, and they are now falling into ruin and disappearing, while some have been restored and converted, mostly into shopping centres. This new function has sometimes harmed some of them. Since they have excellent interior spaces, and still reflect some of the original elements, new functions which related to their specific architectural features must be given to the buildings. On the other hand, by reusing these buildings, we can adapt them to new functions that are responsive to the needs of the residents, by considering that the preservation of their interior layout is essential to achieving successful reuse. The present study intends to examine the factors which cause the deterioration as a direct result of the interaction of political, economic, social and structural forces, and the possibilities of reusing of them. © 2003 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Construction; Deterioration; Structural loads; Interior layout; Buildings; bathing water; building; historical perspective; Europe; Turkey

Authors: Robinson J.S., Culver G.A., Bishop R.D., Bright E.D.
Title: Life cycle analysis of a single stage to orbit (SSTO) reusable launch vehicle
Source title: 39th AIAA/ASME/SAE/ASEE Joint Propulsion Conference and Exhibit
Abstract: At the end of the Apollo program, the United States turned its focus in space transportation towards providing more routine access to space. With the launch of the space shuttle in 1981, the U.S. had its first reusable spaceplane and was on its way toward routine space flight. Since the launch of the first shuttle, many concepts have been proposed to offering improved performance over the space shuttle system. One such class of concepts is hypersonic airbreathing reusable launch vehicles. These vehicles have been analyzed and studied in detail for over the past 40 years. Most of the analysis, however, has focused solely on engine and vehicle performance. Today, both NASA and DoD are placing ever-increasing importance on the system safety, reliability, maintainability, operability, and supportability. This paper will begin to address these issues for one particular concept in the hypersonic airbreathing reusable launch vehicle class. The vehicle is a single stage to orbit, horizontal takeoff and landing system that has heritage to the Access to Space study of 1993. A general description of the concept (called ABLV-4e) is given including its propulsion system design and operating modes, vehicle structural and tank concepts and materials, thermal protection system, and other aspects. System technologies are described, and the vehicle closure is stated for the reference mission (20Klb due East LEO). Following a description of the vehicle performance, detail is provided on the analysis and initial quantification of the system safety, reliability, operability, and cost. Descriptions of the models and assumptions used to quantify each of the characteristics mentioned are included. Also included is a description of the FASTPACT analysis framework developed by SAIC in which these life cycle models and analysis capabilities reside. Finally, initial estimates for Loss of Vehicle, Loss of Mission, Recurring Cost, and Turn-around Time as well as DDT&E and Theoretical First Unit Costs are given. Shortcomings in the analysis tools are discussed, as well as lessons learned and future plans.
Index Keywords: Aerospace vehicles; Cost benefit analysis; Hypersonic vehicles; Launch vehicles; Launching; Life cycle; NASA; Orbits; Reliability analysis; Reusability; Reusable rockets; Space flight; Space shuttles; Analysis capabilities; Analysis frameworks; General description; Life cycle analysis; Reusable launch vehicles; Single stage to orbits; Space transportations; Thermal Protection System; Vehicle performance

Authors: Thuruthimattam B.J., Friedmann P.P., McNamara J.J., Powell K.G.
Title: Modeling approaches to hypersonic aerothermoelasticity with application to reusable launch vehicles
Source title: 44th AIAA/ASME/ASCE/AHS/ASC Structures, Structural Dynamics, and Materials Conference
Abstract: The hypersonic aeroelastic and aerothermoelastic problem of a double-wedge airfoil typical crosssection is studied using three different unsteady aerodynamic loads: (1) third-order piston theory, (2) Euler aerodynamics, and (3) Navier-Stokes aerodynamics. Computational aeroelastic response results are used to obtain frequency and damping characteristics, and compared with those from piston theory solutions for a variety of flight conditions. Aeroelastic behavior is studied for 5 < M < 15 at altitudes of 40,000 and 70,000 feet. A parametric study of offsets, wedge angles, and static angle of attack is conducted. All the solutions are fairly close below the flutter boundary, and differences between the various models increase when the flutter boundary is approached. For this geometry, differences between viscous and inviscid aeroelastic behavior are not substantial. Results illustrate that aerodynamic heating reduces aeroelastic stability. Applying this approach to a generic vehicle resembling a reusable launch vehicle is also discussed. The results presented serve as a partial validation of the CFL3D code for the hypersonic flight regime. © 2003 by B. Thuruthimattan, P. Friedmann, J. McNamara and K. Powell.
Index Keywords: Aerodynamic stability; Angle of attack; Computation theory; Computer software reusability; Flutter (aerodynamics); Hypersonic aerodynamics; Hypersonic vehicles; Launch vehicles; Launching; Navier Stokes equations; Pistons; Reusability; Reusable rockets; Structural dynamics; Aeroelastic behavior; Aeroelastic stability; Damping characteristics; Hypersonic flight regime; Navier-Stokes aerodynamics; Reusable launch vehicles; Third-order piston theories; Unsteady aerodynamic load; Aeroelasticity

Authors: Liu D.D., Chen P.C., Tang L., Chang K.T.
Title: Hypersonic aerothermodynamics/aerothermoelastics methodology for reusable launch vehicles/TPS design and analysis
Abstract: Present design of the reusable launch vehicle (RLV) requires aerothermoelastic design capability to maintain RLV/TPS (Thermal Protection System) structural integrity throughout hypersonic extreme environment. Under AFRL contractual support, ZONA is currently integrating a suite of tools into a ZONA aerothermoelastic software system. This suite of tools includes a high-fidelity hypersonic/supersonic/subsonic panel code (ZONAIR), a prototypical TPS thermal sizing procedure, a robust, yet simplified aerothermodynamic code that is based on a streamline methodology (ZSTREAM), a trajectory analysis code (POST) and a structural optimization software system (ASTROS*). The X-34 is selected as the test case to validate this ZONA aerothermoelastic software system. First, the ZONAIR hypersonic aerodynamic results were well validated with CFD solutions. Next, computed heat rates by applying ZONA aerothermoelastic software to X-34 though two assigned hypersonic trajectories were shown and found to agree well with those using MINIVER. The prototypical TPS thermal sizing procedure was employed to obtain a minimum weight TPS design per hot-wall consideration. Finally, a trim solution and stress distribution for a flexible X-34 at a typical trajectory point were computed using the ASTROS* finite element module (FEM) and the TRIM module, demonstrating the multifunctionality in multi-disciplinary design optimization (MDO) for the present aerothermoelastic software. © Inc. by ZONA Technology.

Authors: Peres E.M.
Title: Product dimensional optimization - Applying and validating GD&T by ASME y 14.5 M
Abstract: This article is the sintezis of vehicle development process, starting from its characteristics and included in a competitive market, and shows the dimensional optimization process application and validation using the GD&T by ASME 14.5 M. Authors: Nhapi I., Dalu J., Ndamba J., Siebel M.A., Gijzen H.J.
Title: An evaluation of duckweed-based pond systems as an alternative option for decentralised treatment and reuse of wastewater in Zimbabwe
Abstract: A study was carried out in Zimbabwe to evaluate the performance of duckweed ponds as an option for treating and reusing wastewater in small, decentralised communities. The study focused on nitrogen and phosphorus removal, operational problems, and duckweed application. Two full-scale trial plants at Nemanwa and Gutu-Mupandawana growth points were used. Sewage samples were collected and analysed monthly from September 2000 to August 2001 for NO3, NH4-, TKN, TP, COD, and other field measurements. The duckweed was harvested daily and fed to chickens. The Nemanwa plant had high nutrient levels due to nil outflows caused by water rationing in the area. The Gutu effluent had averages of 38.7 ± 23.1 mg/l TN and 7.5 ± 2.4 mg/l TP which are above the respective Zimbabwean standards of 10 mg/l TN and 1 mg/l TP. COD removal efficiency at Gutu was poor at 45%. The performance of Gutu and Nemanwa plants suffered from inappropriate design especially pond depth and short-circuiting. The duckweed died off in the November-January period, this being attributed to excessive levels of ammonia. It was concluded that the duckweed pond systems would offer a good alternative for managing and reusing wastewater at community level provided due regard is paid to appropriate design criteria.
Author Keywords: Decentralised; Duckweed; Nutrients; Reuse; Sustainability; Wastewater treatment

Authors: Grönefeld U., Schlenker J.
Title: Reusable panel: Plastic composite panel with replacement film
Abstract: Hünnebeck GmbH developed a reusable panel whose surface can be repaired by machine. The panel is a plastic composite panel fitted with a replacement film. This innovation saves between 35 and 40 percent of cleaning and repair costs as compared to conventional plywood formwork. Furthermore, with the new system, the used material can be recycled and made into new base plates.
Index Keywords: Construction industry; Cost benefit analysis; Recycling; Reusability; Walls (structural partitions); Plastic composite panel; Replacement film; Reusable panel; Plastic building materials

Authors: Stadelmann P., Nagel J.-L., Ansorge M., Pellandini F.
Title: A multiscale morphological coprocessor for low-power face authentication
Abstract: This paper reports a low-power multiscale morphological coprocessor for mobile face authentication devices. In such a system, face verification is performed by extracting mathematical morphology features (erosions and dilations) using a set of structural elements of increasing size. The proposed architecture reduces the number of operations by reusing results, and lowers the amount of needed memory transfers by caching data locally. To improve processing speed at a given operating frequency, four morphological units operate in parallel. Structuring elements can be modified easily as they are described in a table. The architecture was validated using an in-house developed tool, the corresponding simulation results being presented at the end of the paper. © 2002 EUSIPCO.
Index Keywords: Authentication; Signal processing; Co-processors; Face authentication; Face Verification; Operating frequency; Processing speed; Proposed architectures; Structural elements; Structuring element; Mathematical morphology

Authors: Blosser M.L., Chen R.R., Schmidt I.H., Dorsey J.T., Poteet C.C., Bird R.K.
Title: Advanced metallic thermal protection system development
Source title: 40th AIAA Aerospace Sciences Meeting and Exhibit
Abstract: A new Adaptable, Robust, Metallic, Operable, Reusable (ARMOR) thermal protection system (TPS) concept has been designed, analyzed and fabricated. In addition to the inherent, tailorable robustness of metallic TPS, ARMOR TPS offers improved features based on lessons learned from previous metallic TPS development efforts. A specific location on a single-stage-to-orbit reusable launch vehicle was selected to develop loads and requirements needed to design prototype ARMOR TPS panels. The design loads include ascent and entry heating rate histories, pressures, acoustics, and accelerations. Additional TPS design issues were identified and discussed. An iterative sizing procedure was used to size the ARMOR TPS panels for thermal and structural loads as part of an integrated TPS/cryogenic tank structural wall. The TPS panels were sized to maintain acceptable temperatures on the underlying structure and to operate under the design structural loading. Detailed creep analyses were also performed on critical components of the ARMOR TPS panels. A lightweight, thermally compliant TPS support system (TPSS) was designed to connect the TPS to the cryogenic tank structure. Four 18-inch-square ARMOR TPS panels were fabricated. Details of the fabrication process are presented. Details of the TPSS for connecting the ARMOR TPS panels to the externally stiffened cryogenic tank structure are also described. Test plans for the fabricated hardware are presented. © 2001 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc.

Authors: Youssef H., Chowdhry R., Lee H., Carty A.
Title: RLV aero surfaces optimization subject to stability and control constraints
Source title: AIAA Guidance, Navigation, and Control Conference and Exhibit
Abstract: A new methodology is developed to optimize the aero surfaces using model center tools in rapid conceptual design (RCD) environment. The objective function is based on minimizing the total aero surfaces weight while meeting the trim requirements and the targeted level of stability augmentation along the entire entry trajectory for reusable launch vehicle (RLV). The trajectory is divided in regions where angle of attack (AOA)-alpha and bank angle-sigma are parameterized to allow for trajectory reshaping during the optimization of surfaces sizing. The aero surfaces parameters used in the optimization are canted fin area and incidence angle, and flap area. Usually, the entry portion of the trajectory is designed to yield maximized downrange subject to structural load and aero-thermal constraints. In this paper, the trajectory optimization and aero surfaces sizing are combined in new formulation. That is to minimize the aero surfaces weight while maintaining the optimum performance. The total process is performed in RCD environment with the aide of model center analysis tools. The proof of concept is demonstrated using the RLV example in Reference. © 2002 by the author(s). Published by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc.
Index Keywords: Angle of attack; Conceptual design; Reusability; Angle of attacks (AOA); Objective functions; Optimum performance; Re-usable launch vehicles (RLV); Stability and control; Stability augmentations; Thermal constraints; Trajectory optimization; Trajectories

Authors: Chen R.R., Blosser M.L.
Title: Metallic thermal protection system panel flutter study
Source title: 40th AIAA Aerospace Sciences Meeting and Exhibit
Abstract: Panel flutter analysis results of a reusable launch vehicle metallic thermal protection system [Ref.1] panel are presented in this paper. Panel flutter is a self-excited aeroelastic vibration. The unsteady aerodynamic theory used in this study is the first- and second-order piston theory. The analysis capability is incorporated into a commercial finite element code with the goal of providing a useful tool for aerospace engineers -MSC/MARC [Ref.6]. The capability consists of three parts: linear flutter analysis, linear flutter analysis with arbitrary flow direction, and nonlinear hypersonic flutter analysis. Structural nonlinearities are not considered. The current paper covers both panel flutter analysis tool development as well as parametric panel flutter study of a specific metallic TPS configuration. The resulting analytical tool was used to analyze a metallic TPS being built for the X-33 experimental vehicle. The results show that nonlinear, hypersonic aerodynamic terms were found to have an insignificant effect on the panel flutter predictions for the X-33 TPS. The honeycomb sandwich that comprises most of the outer surface of the X-33 TPS panel was found to have large margins of safety for panel flutter for all flight conditions. However, the outer overlapping, panel-to-panel seals were predicted to be susceptible to panel flutter when nearly parallel to the flow. © 2002 by American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc.
Index Keywords: Heat shielding; Hypersonic vehicles; Metals; Reusability; Thermal insulating materials; Aeroelastic vibration; Analysis capabilities; Commercial finite element codes; Experimental vehicle; Metallic thermal protection system; Reusable launch vehicles; Structural non-linearities; Unsteady aerodynamics; Flutter (aerodynamics)

Authors: Probst S., Essmayr W., Weippl E.
Title: Reusable components for developing security-aware applications
Source title: Proceedings - Annual Computer Security Applications Conference, ACSAC
Abstract: Today, security is considered to be an important aspect of multi-tier application development. Thoroughly researched concepts for access control exist and have been proven in mainframe computing. However, they are often not used in today's development of multi-tier applications. One reason may be the lack of appropriate reusable components that support application developers that frequently have to re-invent the wheel when it comes to access controls. The goal of this paper is to promote awareness of security issues when developing applications and to illustrate a suitable approach for that. Our framework called GAMMA (Generic Authorization Mechanisms for Multi-Tier Applications) offers several authentication, access control, and auditing mechanisms. Access control models can be combined or used simultaneously in order to provide application-specific and highly customizable mechanisms. Moreover, due to its component-based structure, new security models and additional approaches for authentication or auditing can easily be added. © 2002 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Access control; Application software; Authentication; Authorization; Computer architecture; Connectors; Cryptography; Data security; Software reusability; Wheels

Authors: Glushko R.J., McGrath T.
Title: Document Engineering for e-Business
Source title: Proceedings of the 2002 ACM Symposium on Document Engineering
Abstract: It can be said that "document exchange" is the "mother of all patterns" for business (and for e-business). Yet by itself this view isn't sufficiently prescriptive. In this paper, we present additional perspectives or frameworks that make this abstraction more rigorous and useful. We describe an approach to artifact-driven analysis, model refinement, and implementation for document-intensive systems that unifies the "document analysis" approach from publishing and the "data analysis" approach from information systems. These traditionally contrasting approaches to understanding documents are unified in an "Analysis Spectrum" in which presentational, structural, and content components assume different weights or status. Our methodology emphasizes reuse with a "Reuse Matrix," in which both business process (or document exchange) patterns and document schema patterns are organized by different levels of abstraction and scope. Enterprise-level patterns like "supply chain" and "marketplace" can fit into this matrix along with process patterns like "RosettaNet PIP" and document patterns like the "XML Common Business Library." Taken together, these concepts form the foundation of a new discipline: "Document Engineering for e-Business.".
Author Keywords: Business Process Modeling; Document Analysis; Document Engineering; E-Business; Patterns; Reuse; XML
Index Keywords: Electronic commerce; Interfaces (computer); Internet; XML; Document engineering; Program documentation

Authors: Zhu H., Thong-On N., Zhang X.
Title: Adding crumb rubber into exrerior wall materials
Abstract: In Arizona US, most houses are built with walls covered by stuccos/coatings/mortars. This paper presents an explorative investigation of adding crumb rubber into stuccos/coatings/mortars. A series of experiments are conducted to examine the thermal and mechanical performance of the crumb rubber mixes. The results show that, the mixes with crumb rubber do exhibit more desirable performances like being high in crack-resistance and thermal insulation, and low in thermal expansion/contraction. The drawback for the crumb rubber mixes is the reduction in compressive strength, but which can be compensated by other means. As a site experiment, an area of 100 square-feet of crumb rubber coatings for two mix designs is sprayed on a tire-adobe wall. After being sprayed more than 14 months, the coatings apparently are in good condition. Significance of this study is that this practice, if accepted, will yield improved products that consume large quantities of crumb rubber.
Author Keywords: Coatings; Cracking; Crumb rubber; Exterior wall materials; Mortar; Reuse; Stucco; Waste tire; Wmr 542-3

Authors: Gee K.
Title: Vehicle analysis using an agent-based analysis tools framework
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME Design Engineering Technical Conference
Abstract: Methods to combine a number of analysis tools into an agent-based integrated design system (IDS) for aerospace vehicles were developed. Computer-aided Design (CAD) and Finite Element Method (FEM) thermal and structural analysis packages were integrated with low-fidelity aero- and thermodynamic methods and high-fidelity CFD flow solvers Analyses were characterized by the generation of an FEM unstructured grid from the CAD data, generation of a structured grid from the FEM grid, computation of the aerodynamic solution, interpolation of the flow data onto the FEM grid, and solution of the thermal and/or structural response of the geometry to the aerodynamic loading. A level of autonomy was provided by an expert system that managed the input data, selected the appropriate flow solver, and built the required input files. The ability to dynamically link available tools together to solve a given problem was also included The framework integrated commercial tools to enable the use of distributed, heterogeneous computing systems. The framework was used to analyze the effect of wedge angle and nose radius on the heating characteristics of the nose region of a reusable launch vehicle.
Author Keywords: Agents; CFD; FEM; Framework; Multidisciplinary

Authors: Kano M., Ohyoshi T.
Title: On the measure of modularity for eco-products design
Source title: Proceedings of the Fourth International Conference on Materials Engineering for Resources
Abstract: New measures for designing the module structures are proposed and they are useful for making environment conscious industrial products. The quantitative handling of modularity will viable as indicators of complex industrial products to improve their design for keeping good environment of the earth by reducing materials, reusing parts and recycling resources. The calculation of measure is based upon the state of common properties among product components taking numerical weight factors into account. Their common properties can be selected flexibly depending on social demands as well as producer's and user's demands. Application study to a mouse of PC input controller device has been demonstrated here. The result shows that the measures are helpful to estimate module structures. The development of desired module structures by making use of the measures will be the main work for engineers to promote the circulatory society.
Author Keywords: Eco-Products; Measure of Modularity; Mechanical Design; Modular Structure; Reuse

Authors: Aoki T., Ishikawa T., Morino Y.
Title: Overview of basic research activities on cryogenic composite propellant tanks in Japan
Source title: 10th AIAA/NAL-NASDA-ISAS International Space Planes and Hypersonic Systems and Technologies Conference
Abstract: Extensive application of composite materials is one of the major technical challenges for drastic reduction of structural weight of the planned space planes and reusable launch vehicles (RLV). Propellant tanks are the dominating structural components of the vehicle structure and thus the application of carbon fiber reinforced plastics (CFRP) to these components is one of the most promising but challenging technologies for achieving the goal of weight reduction. The overview of current activities on basic research related to the application of CFRP to cryogenic propellant tanks in Japan is given. These research projects indicate that the load-carrying performance of the state-of-the-art material systems is at the sufficient level to be used in the CFRP tanks, leaving the problems related to permeability, durability and fabrication yet to be extensively investigated. The preliminary evaluations of thermal insulation materials and adhesive materials are also under way at NASDA. The research project led by NAL-Kakuda also exhibits the promising results of the CFRP components. © 2001 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Adhesives; Automobile manufacture; Carbon fiber reinforced plastics; Computer software reusability; Cryogenics; Glass ceramics; Hypersonic vehicles; Launching; Propellants; Spacecraft propulsion; Tanks (containers); Thermal insulation; Carbon fiber reinforced plastics (CFRP); Cryogenic propellant tanks; Re-usable launch vehicles (RLV); Research activities; Structural component; Technical challenges; Thermal insulation materials; Vehicle structures; Composite propellants

Authors: Collivignarelli C., Sorlini S.
Title: Optimisation of industrial wastes reuse as construction materials
Abstract: This study concerns the reuse of two inorganic wastes, foundry residues and fly ashes from municipal solid waste incineration, as "recycled aggregate" in concrete production. This kind of reuse was optimised by waste treatment with the following steps: waste washing with water; waste stabilisation-solidification treatment with inorganic reagents; final grinding of the stabilised waste after curing for about 10-20 days. Both the treated wastes were reused in concrete production with different mix-designs. Concrete specimens were characterised by means of conventional physical-mechanical tests (compression, elasticity modulus, shrinkage) and different leaching tests. Experimental results showed that a good structural and environmental quality of "recycled concrete" is due both to a correct waste treatment and to a correct mix-design for concrete mixture.

Authors: Lamberti L., Venkataratnan S., Haftka R.T., Johnson T.F.
Title: Comparison of preliminary designs of stiffened panels optimized using PANDA2 for reusable launch vehicle propellant tanks
Source title: 41st  Structures, Structural Dynamics, and Materials Conference and Exhibit
Abstract: Preliminary design of reusable launch vehicles often entails a large number of structural optimizations in the conceptual design phase to investigate the weight efficiency of different structural concepts. This work addresses two topics. The first topic concerns modeling and analysis methods used for stiffened panel optimization. In particular, the use of PANDA2 program for preliminary design, and the effect of different analysis and modeling choices in PANDA2 on optimum design are investigated. The second topic is comparison of weight efficiency of different stiffening concepts for a liquid hydrogen tank structure design. Optimized metallic and composite designs and their failure modes and margins are compared. Sensitivity to geometric imperfections is also studied. © 2000 by Satchi Venkataraman.

Authors: Scherer R.J., Reul S.
Title: Retrieval of project knowledge from heterogeneous AEC documents
Source title: Computing in Civil and Building Engineering
Abstract: A knowledge system for the retrieval of project knowledge from civil-engineering documents will be described from different views. The views demonstrate the research process, the knowledge acquisition process and the recovery structure of the knowledge system. The described knowledge system should provide the possibility to reuse construction knowledge locked in documents. The documents will be classified using text analysing methods combined with clustering techniques. A lexicon which includes important parts of knowledge like construction key words, synonyms etc. for the specific domain of the building process will be combined with a document class structure and project class structure. During the process of general text analyses the lexicon will be completed with the frequency of words structured in different clusters of the building process. The knowledge system built up, will be a long-term storage of project experiences for the building industry.
Index Keywords: Engineering research; Knowledge acquisition; Knowledge based systems; Knowledge engineering; Project management; Reusability; Structural analysis; Lexicon; Project knowledge; Civil engineering

Authors: Donahue B.B.
Title: Two stage to orbit launch vehicles for delivering heavy payloads to low earth orbit
Source title: 36th AIAA/ASME/SAE/ASEE Joint Propulsion Conference and Exhibit
Abstract: This report presents four approaches to configuring large, all rocket, two-stage-to-orbit launch vehicles for delivering heavy payloads to low Earth orbit. The pay load capability for each configuration is 176,000 Ibs launched due east into a 220 nautical mile circular orbit. This capability was chosen so as to be comparable to the payload capability of the Shuttle derived Magnum expendable heavy lift launch vehicle concept characterized by NASA in 1999. In the first option presented, a reusable, winged stage is used to boost a parallel burn, expendable core stage to LEO. For the second option, both the booster and orbiter are winged, reusable stages. The third option differs from second only in the fuel type used by the booster stage. The fourth configuration differs in that the winged, reusable orbiter utilizes an expendable payload shroud, rather than an internal payload bay. Its forward shroud is mounted to the orbiter s nose structure via a special structural attachment. Design trades investigated include reusability, propellant selection, engine choice, and booster separation condition, among others. Results indicate that a heavy lift Earth-to-Orbit strategy should consider using a shared reusable booster. The booster should be a common component of another two-stage-to-orbit launch system, to boost smaller core stages. This would allow recouping the boosters initial nonrecurring costs across a larger number of missions and programs. © The Boeing Company, all rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Aerospace vehicles; Communication satellites; Launch vehicles; NASA; Orbits; Propulsion; Reusability; Rockets; Booster separation; Earth to orbits; Heavy-lift launch vehicles; Low earth orbits; Non-recurring costs; Payload capabilities; Reusable boosters; Two stage to orbits; Boosters (rocket)

Authors: Blades E.L., Redgrave G.W.
Title: Captive carry flutter analysis for the X-34 reusable launch vehicle
Source title: 41st  Structures, Structural Dynamics, and Materials Conference and Exhibit
Abstract: This work was done to determine if the L-1011/X-34 captive carry configuration is free from flutter within the flight envelope in order to obtain FAA approval and avoid flight flutter testing. After conducting a flutter analysis for the L-1011 carrier aircraft, a flutter analysis was conducted for the mated configuration. The X-34 was shown to have no significant effect on the critical flutter margins of the L-1011. The addition of the X-34 did not introduce any new critical flutter mechanisms to the system. © 2000 by Structural Dynamics Research Corporation.
Index Keywords: Flight envelopes; Free flight; Reusability; Structural dynamics; Carrier aircraft; Flight flutter testing; Flutter analysis; Flutter margin; Flutter mechanisms; Reusable launch vehicles; Flutter (aerodynamics)

Authors: Brown A.M.
Title: Temperature-dependent modal test/analysis correlation of X-34 Fastrac composite rocket nozzle
Source title: 41st  Structures, Structural Dynamics, and Materials Conference and Exhibit
Abstract: A unique high-temperature modal test and model correlation/update program has been performed on the composite nozzle of the FASTRAC engine for the NASA X-34 reusable launch vehicle. The program was required to provide an accurate high-temperature model of the nozzle for incorporation into the engine system structural dynamics model for loads calculation; this model is significantly different from the ambient case due to the large decrease in composite material properties attributable to heating. The modal test was enabled by piggybacking onto a hot-fire test of the nozzle at NASA Marshall Space Flight Center (MSFC) and tracking the natural frequencies as they decreased. A series of high-fidelity modal tests and finite element model correlation of the nozzle in a free-free configuration was initially performed. This model was then attached to a modal test-verified model of the engine hot-fire test stand and the ambient system mode shapes identified. A reduced set of accelerometers was then attached to the nozzle, the engine fired full duration, and the frequency peaks corresponding to the ambient nozzle modes individually isolated and tracked. To update the finite element model of the nozzle to these frequency curves, a multiplicative factor was applied to the rate of decline of the composite material property versus temperature table. This new property table was used to create high-temperature nozzle models corresponding to 10-sec engine operation increments and tied into the engine system model for loads determination. © 2000 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and, Astronautics, Inc.

Authors: Bradley D.
Title: Risbygate Street regeneration, Bury St Edmunds
Source title: Proceedings of the Institution of Civil Engineers: Municipal Engineer
Abstract: Risbygate Street was a prosperous street in fifteenth century but its neglect and decay had set in by 1980s. In the 1990s, the introduction of Conservation Area Partnership Schemes (CAPS) was made by English Heritage to introduce new lease of life into the street and secure the repair and reuse of the historic buildings. In total, 45 new residential units and ten new retail units were created. The street was a thriving area once more.
Index Keywords: Buildings; Public policy; Strategic planning; Urban planning; Building preservation; Historic buildings; Urban regeneration; Reconstruction (structural)

Authors: Bennert T.A., Maher M.H., Jafari F., Gucunski N.
Title: Use of dredged sediments from newark harbor for geotechnical applications
Abstract: Under the Joint Dredging Plan for the Port of New York and New Jersey, New Jersey has committed to using stabilized dredged material for beneficial reuse. Under the short-term planning (1997-2000), an annual average of 1.39 million cubic meters of dredged material must be used. Laboratory tests were conducted to investigate the geotechnical properties of the Newark Harbor dredged sediments stabilized with portland cement. The material properties and strength characteristics were investigated using soil characterization, California Bearing Ratio, unconfined compression, unconsolidated undrained and consolidated undrained triaxial compression, and resilient modulus tests. Currently, portland cement stabilized dredged material is being placed as a subgrade layer for a future parking lot. Cone penetration testing was conducted on the material to evaluate the in-situ density of the deeper, compacted layers. Nuclear density tests were also conducted to verify compaction of the material. Correlations between the two in situ tests were developed to analyze the two-meter-deep structural fill.
Author Keywords: Beneficial reuse; Cone penetration; Dredged sediments; Laboratory tests; Newark harbor; Nuclear density test; Subgrade
Index Keywords: Building materials; Compression testing; Consolidation; Dredging; Portland cement; Ports and harbors; Sediments; Soil mechanics; Soil testing; Cone penetration testing; Dredged sediments; Nuclear density testing; Geotechnical engineering
